title: Quality improvements not reflected in CPI

content.question: Which of the following is an example of how the consumer price index <math alttext="open parenthesis, C P I, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>I</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> exhibits bias in its estimates of changes in the cost of living?

choices.label: Energy prices have a higher impact on inflation than other input costs do.
New products are always overrepresented in the <math alttext="C P I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>PI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="C P I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>PI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> assigns greater weight to measures of welfare than it does to economic activity.

Product improvements are not always fully reflected in the calculation of the <math alttext="C P I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>PI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The <math alttext="C P I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>PI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> adjusts for the substitution of less expensive goods by consumers.

content.answer: Product improvements are not always fully reflected in the calculation of the <math alttext="C P I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>PI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
